member.name: T:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BaseNCodec
member.summary: Implements Base-64, Base-32 and Base-16 encoding and decoding of binary data, as described in RFC 4648: http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648 Selection of the encoding is determined by which alphabet is used; the alphabet size must be 65 for Base-64, 33 for Base-32, or 16 for Base-16 (which doesn't require padding, hence no extra padding character).
member.comments: Only encoding is currently implemented, as we haven't had a need for decoding yet.

member.name: F:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BaseNCodec.BASE_64_STANDARD
member.summary: The default Base-64 alphabet as described in the RFC.

member.name: F:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BaseNCodec.BASE_64_URLSAFE
member.summary: URL- and filename-safe Base-64 alphabet from the RFC.

member.name: F:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BaseNCodec.BASE_32_STANDARD
member.summary: The default Base-32 alphabet from the RFC.

member.name: F:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BaseNCodec.BASE_32_EXTENDED_HEX
member.summary: A Base-32 alphabet based on extending hexadecimal notation, as described in the RFC.

member.name: F:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BaseNCodec.BASE_16_STANDARD
member.summary: Normal hexadecimal encoding for Base-16.

member.name: M:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BaseNCodec.Encode(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Encode binary data into a string. This function will attempt to autodetect the number of bits per output character from the alphabet size, and can handle 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 or 7 bits at a time. Non-power-of-two bit sizes require a padding character, and thus an odd-sized alphabet. Padding characters are added to achieve a standard quantum, which is the least common multiple of 8 and the number of encoding bits. This implementation does not output linefeeds.
member.param: Buffer containing the data to encode.
Index of the first byte to encode from the buffer.
Number of bytes to encode from the buffer.
Encoding alphabet to use.
member.returns: A string representing the binary data encoded with the given alphabet.
member.exception: The start index and length arguments specify a range that is outside of the bounds of the input data buffer.
The input data buffer or alphabet string is null.
The alphabet size is inappropriate.

member.name: T:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BitStreamReader
member.summary: Helper to read odd numbers of bits from a stream of bytes. Up to 64 bits can be read at a time. The most significant bit of the first byte of input becomes the first bit read, which becomes the most significant bit of whatever size is read. The least significant bit of the first input byte is the 8th bit read, and the MSB of the second byte is the 9th bit, and so on. If the end of the input is reached, the last remaining input bits will become the most significant bits of the last output, and the remainder of the output will be zeroed.

member.name: M:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BitStreamReader.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialize a new BitStreamReader to read from a given memory buffer.
member.param: The boffer to read from.
Index of the first byte to read in the buffer.
Number of bytes to read from the buffer.
member.exception: The inputs describe a sequence of bytes outside the bounds of the buffer.
The input buffer is null.

member.name: M:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BitStreamReader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Initialize a new BitStreamReader to read from an existing stream.
member.param: The stream to read from.
member.exception: The stream is null.

member.name: M:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BitStreamReader.Dispose
member.summary: Dispose of resources held by this class instance, if any.

member.name: M:Zaber.FirmwareDownload.BitStreamReader.ReadBits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Read some bits from the input.
member.param: Number of bits to read. Legal range is 1 to 64.
member.returns: A 64-bit value containing the desired bits at the low end, with the first bit read as the most significant of those and the last bit read as the LSB. If the end of the input data is reached, further output is all zero bits.
member.exception: The count input has an illegal value.

member.returns: The new (possibly encrypted) firmware image for the device.

The file does not exist
The path is in an invalid format.
The file header is incorrect or the file is otherwise corrupted.
The unpacker attempted to read past the end of the input stream.
Decoding the data produced a message instead of a result.

member.name: T:Zaber.FirmwareVersion
member.summary: A struct to represent the firmware version present on a device.
member.remarks: Previously, firmware version was stored as a 3-digit integer, with the first digit (the "100's digit") representing the major version, and the following two digits representing the minor version. This matched the way Zaber's firmware reported its firmware version. For this reason, operator overloads are provided for comparing this struct to integers. Note that when comparing to integers, build number is ignored.

member.name: T:Zaber.Conversation
member.summary: Converts from the asynchronous, event-driven model of the to a synchronous, request/response model.
member.remarks: When you call the method, the conversation will call on its device, and then sleep until a response is returned. See the method notes for details on support for message ids and pitfalls to avoid.

member.name: P:Zaber.Conversation.RetryCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of times to retry a request after a port error. Defaults to 0.
member.remarks: By default, when the port raises its event, any waiting conversation topics throw a . However, you can set this property to make the conversation retry the request a few times before throwing the exception. Only commands that are safe will be retried. For example, Move Relative cannot be retried, it will always throw an exception if a port error occurs.

member.name: P:Zaber.Conversation.AreUnexpectedResponsesInvalid
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag for whether unexpected responses should be reported as invalid.
member.exception: when this conversation's device does not have message ids enabled
member.remarks: If this flag is true, then only responses with a known message id will be processed. Any responses with an unknown message id or no message id will trigger . The advantage to setting this is that corrupted responses won't accidentally trigger a . If you do set this, you should probably use the property to avoid having a thread that hangs forever.

member.summary: Send a command to a Zaber device that doesn't require a data value and wait for the response.
member.param: See .

member.exception: Another request has replaced this request.
The response was .
A port error occurred while waiting for a response.
The request did not complete before the timeout expired.
member.remarks: See more details in the other override of .

member.name: M:Zaber.Conversation.Request(Zaber.Command,System.Int32)
member.summary: Send a command to a Zaber device and wait for the response.
member.param: See .
See .
member.returns: The response message
member.exception: Another request has replaced this request.
The response was .
A port error occurred while waiting for a response.
The request did not complete before the timeout expired.

remarks.para: This method sends the request on to the device and then puts the thread to sleep until a response is received or the times out. However, there are some situations where it can get confused about which response goes with which request.

If message ids are enabled on the device, then coordinating requests and responses is reliable. There were some bugs in the firmware related to message ids, so make sure your firmware is at least version 5.07.

If message ids are disabled (the default), then the following scenarios can cause errors:
You request a pre-emptable command from the conversation, and while it is running, a joystick sends a command to the same device. The conversation didn't see the request, so it assumes that the response is for the message it sent and returns it normally.
You request a command from the conversation, and just as it starts, another thread requests another command. Depending on the timing, the conversation may not record the requests in the same order they get sent to the device, and the conversation may return your command's response to the other thread and the other command's response to you.
You request a command from the conversation, and just as it finishes, another thread requests another command. Depending on the timing, the conversation may return your command's response to the other thread and the other command's response to you.

member.param: The command to send to the device without the slash or device number.
member.returns: The response message
member.exception: The response was an error.

No response was received before the timeout expired.

remarks.para: This method sends the request on to the device and then puts the thread to sleep until a response is received or the times out.

member.name: M:Zaber.Conversation.StartTopic
member.summary: Record that a request is about to be made.
member.returns: The topic that will monitor the request.

remarks.para: You can then make the request using the device directly and call to wait for the response. This is useful if you want to make several unrelated requests of several devices and then wait until they are all completed. If message ids are enabled, be sure to use the message id from the topic when sending the request.

If message ids are disabled, then this technique is not thread-safe, because there's no guarantee that two requests from two threads will get sent to the device in the same order that their topics were started. If you're sending requests to one device from more than one thread, either enable message ids, or implement your own locking at a higher level.

member.exception: All message IDs are in use in other pending conversations.

member.summary: Record that a request is about to be made.
member.returns: The topic that will monitor the request.
member.param: The message id that the request will use.

remarks.para: You can then make the request using the device directly and call to wait for the response. This is useful if you want to make several unrelated requests of several devices and then wait until they are all completed. If message ids are disabled, messageId will be ignored.

If message ids are disabled, then this technique is not thread-safe, because there's no guarantee that two requests from two threads will get sent to the device in the same order that their topics were started. If you're sending requests to one device from more than one thread, either enable message ids, or implement your own locking at a higher level.

member.exception: A topic already exists with the specified message ID.

member.name: T:Zaber.ConversationCollection
member.summary: Treats a collection of conversations as a single conversation. Useful for making requests from aliases (including the "all devices" alias on device number 0). When you make a request, it waits for a response from every conversation in the collection before it returns.

member.summary: Create a new instance.
member.param: The device that this conversation will send single requests through.

member.name: P:Zaber.ConversationCollection.AreUnexpectedResponsesInvalid
member.summary: Gets or sets a flag for whether unexpected responses should be reported as invalid.
member.exception: when this conversation's device does not have message ids enabled
member.remarks: If this flag is true, then only responses with a known message id will be processed. Any responses with an unknown message id or no message id will trigger . The advantage to setting this is that corrupted responses won't accidentally trigger a . If you do set this, you should probably use the property to avoid having a thread that hangs forever. Setting this on a conversation collection will set it on all members of the collection.

member.name: P:Zaber.ConversationCollection.RetryCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of times to retry a request after a port error. Defaults to 0.
member.remarks: By default, when the port raises its event, any waiting conversation topics throw a . However, you can set this property to make the conversation retry the request a few times before throwing the exception. Only commands that are safe will be retried. For example, Move Relative cannot be retried, it will always throw an exception if a port error occurs. Setting this on a conversation collection will set it on all members of the collection.

member.name: M:Zaber.ConversationCollection.Request(Zaber.Command,System.Int32)
member.summary: Send a request to a Zaber device collection and wait for the responses from all its member devices.
member.param: See .
See .
member.returns: The response message from the first conversation in the list.
member.exception: At least one conversation in the list raised an exception. The detailed responses and exceptions are available from the exception as a list of objects.
Some of the requests did not complete before the timeout expired.
member.remarks: This method sends the request on to this conversation's device and then puts the thread to sleep until a response is received from every conversation in the list. However, there are some situations where it can get confused about which response goes with which request. See for details.

member.name: M:Zaber.ConversationCollection.StartTopic(System.Byte)
member.summary: Record that a request is about to be made.
member.param: The message id that the request will use.
member.returns: The topic that will monitor the request.

remarks.para: You can then make the request using the device directly and call to wait for the response. This is useful if you want to make several unrelated requests of several devices and then wait until they are all completed. If message ids are enabled, be sure to use the message id from the topic when sending the request.

If message ids are disabled, then this technique is not thread-safe, because there's no guarantee that two requests from two threads will get sent to the device in the same order that their topics were started. If you're sending requests to one device from more than one thread, either enable message ids, or implement your own locking at a higher level.

member.name: M:Zaber.ConversationCollection.StartTopicCollection
member.summary: Record that a request is about to be made to several devices.
member.returns: The topic that will monitor the request.

remarks.para: You can then make the request using the devices directly and call to wait for the response. This is useful if you want to make several unrelated requests of several devices and then wait until they are all completed. If message ids are enabled, be sure to use the message id from the topic when sending the request.

If message ids are disabled, then this technique is not thread-safe, because there's no guarantee that two requests from two threads will get sent to the device in the same order that their topics were started. If you're sending requests to one device from more than one thread, either enable message ids, or implement your own locking at a higher level.

member.name: M:Zaber.ConversationCollection.RequestCollection(Zaber.Command,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Send a request to several conversations and coordinate all the responses.
member.param: See .

An array of data values. One will be sent to each conversation in the list. There are two special cases: one entry and no entries. An array with one entry will be used to send a single request to this conversation's device and then the thread will block until a response is received from every conversation in the list. An array with no entries is the same as one entry with value 0. See .
member.returns: A list of response messages in the same order that the conversations appear in the list.
member.exception: At least one request in the list raised an exception. The detailed responses and exceptions are available from the exception as a list of objects.
Some of the requests did not complete before the timeout expired.
member.remarks:
This method sends the request on to the device and then puts the thread to sleep until a response is received from every device in the collection. However, there are some situations where it can get confused about which response goes with which request. See
for details.

member.name: T:Zaber.ConversationTopicCollection
member.summary: A collection of objects. It's used to represent a topic in a .
member.remarks: This class is both a ConversationTopic and a collection of them. Waiting for it waits for all its items to complete. The class is almost completely thread-safe. The only exception is the method. Enumerating through the collection while other threads are marking its items as completed or adding or removing items is not safe. A safe alternative would be to call and then iterate through the array, but remember that you wouldn't see any changes to the collection that occurred after the call to CopyTo.

member.name: T:Zaber.LoopbackException
member.summary: A loopback connection was detected on a serial port.
member.remarks: A loopback connection is a connection from the serial port's send pin to the receive pin. This makes it appear as though the serial port is receiving a copy of every byte it sends. This can happen intentionally when a loopback dongle is connected to the serial port, or unintentionally when wires are connected incorrectly.

member.name: T:Zaber.PlugIns.IPlugInManager
member.summary: An interface that plug ins can use to pass data between them.
member.remarks: If one plug in wants to send data to another one, it can declare a property of type IPlugInManager. Then it calls manager.SetProperty() to pass data to any plug ins with properties of that type. If you want to have more than one property of the same type, use names for the properties.

member.name: M:Zaber.PlugIns.IPlugInManager.SetProperty(System.Object,System.Type)
member.summary: Set a property of the given type on any plug ins that have one.
member.param: The value to pass to each plug in.
The type of property to set. Any properties of this type or its subtypes will be set.

member.name: M:Zaber.PlugIns.IPlugInManager.SetProperty(System.Object,System.Type,System.String)
member.summary: Set a property of the given type and name on any plug ins that have one.
member.param: The value to pass to each plug in.
The type of property to set. Any properties of this type or its subtypes will be set.
The name of the property. This will match the name declared in the . The default name is null.

member.name: T:Zaber.PlugIns.PlugInPropertyAttribute
member.summary: Mark a plug in's property to be automatically set by the host program.
member.remarks: Only properties of certain types will be set by the host program: will receive the active port facade, will receive the selected conversation from the port facade, System.IO.TextReader will receive a user input stream if the host program has one, System.IO.TextWriter will receive a user output stream if the host has one. Other property types can be used together with the . This lets one plug in pass data to other plug ins.

member.name: P:Zaber.PlugIns.PlugInPropertyAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name for this property. If a plug in needs more than one property of the same type, you can distinguish between them with different names.
member.remarks: Named properties are only set when another plugin calls . The default name of null counts as a separate name, so you could have one string property without a name, and another string property with a name, and they would be set independently. The name works in combination with the type, so if another plug in sets a property with the same name, but an incompatible type, then this property will not be set.

member.name: T:Zaber.PlugIns.PlugInAttribute
member.summary: Mark a class as a plug in to be used in a Zaber library client program.
member.remarks: The class must also derive from System.Windows.Forms.Control. Deriving from UserControl is the simplest.

member.name: P:Zaber.PlugIns.PlugInAttribute.Name
member.summary: Declare a name to be used for display in the client program. Defaults to the class name.

member.summary: Find the default file in the folder.
member.param: Specifies the file extensions you want to look for

member.remarks: We look for files that are named Default.* where .* is one of the extensions supported by the language.

member.name: M:Zaber.PlugIns.FileFinder.FindFile(System.String)
member.summary: Find the named file in the folder.
member.param: The name of the file to find. It may contain wild cards.
member.returns: The requested file, or null if it could not be found
member.remarks: We search the folder for the named file. If more than one file matches the request, the first one is returned.

member.name: M:Zaber.PlugIns.FileFinder.IsFindable(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a file could be found by this finder.
member.param: The full path to the file.

member.name: T:Zaber.PlugIns.IFileFinder
member.summary: Search features for files in a specific folder.

member.name: M:Zaber.PlugIns.IFileFinder.FindDefaultFile(Zaber.PlugIns.ScriptLanguage)
member.summary: Find the default file in the folder.
member.param: Specifies the file extensions you want to look for
member.returns: The requested file or null if none could be found.
member.remarks:
First, we find all files with an extension supported by the language parameter. The default is determined using the first rule that applies:
If we only find one file, it's the default.
If one of the files is named Default.*, it's the default.
The file names are sorted alphabetically, and the first one is the default.

member.summary: Find the named file in the folder.

member.returns: The requested file, or null if it could not be found
member.remarks: We search the folder for the named file. If more than one file matches the request, the first one is returned.

Pairs of units with the old unit followed by the new unit

The unit of measure to convert to.
One from unit is equal to this many to units.

member.summary: Copy the ratios from the source table, and add any new conversions.

The index of the to unit in the new table.

The unit to convert to.

member.name: T:Zaber.ScalingFunction
member.summary: Describes scaling functions which are to be applied to convert between real-life units of measure and Zaber device data units.

member.name: F:Zaber.ScalingFunction.Linear
member.summary: Device units = scale * physical units.

member.name: F:Zaber.ScalingFunction.Reciprocal
member.summary: Device units = scale / physical units.

member.name: F:Zaber.ScalingFunction.LinearResolution
member.summary: Device units = scale * resolution * physical units.

member.name: F:Zaber.ScalingFunction.TangentialResolution
member.summary: Device units = scale * resolution * tan(physical units * Pi / 180)
member.remarks: Warning: This formula can only be applied to absolute positions. It is not applicable to relative positions, velocities, or accelerations.

member.name: F:Zaber.StreamExtensions.Endianness.Big
member.summary: Value is stored big-endian (MSB first) in a stream.

member.summary: Read a 16-bit unsigned integer from a stream, endian-swapping if necessary to host order.

The endianness of the value's representation in the stream.
member.returns: The value read from 2 bytes at the current position in the stream.

member.exception: The read attempt would pass the end of the input stream.

Buffer to read to.
Index within the buffer to start writing bytes.
Number of bytes to transfer from the stream to the buffer.

member.name: T:Zaber.DeviceModes
member.summary: Bits used to set the flags in the command.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.None
member.summary: No modes are enabled

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.DisableAutoReply
member.summary: Disables ALL replies except those to "return" commands (commands 50 and higher).

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.EnableAntiBacklashRoutine
member.summary: Enables anti-backlash. On negative moves (retracting), the device will overshoot the desired position by 640 microsteps (assuming 64 microsteps/step), reverse direction and approach the requested position from below. On positive moves (extending), the device behaves normally. Care must be taken not to crash the moving payload into a fixed object due to the 640 microsteps overshoot on negative moves.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.EnableAntiSticktionRoutine
member.summary: Enables the anti-sticktion routine. On moves less than 640 microsteps (assuming 64 microsteps/step), the device will first retract to a position 640 microsteps less than the requested position and approach the requested position from below. Care must be taken not to crash the moving payload into a fixed object due to the 640 microsteps negative move.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.DisablePotentiometer
member.summary: Disables the potentiometer preventing manual adjustment of the device.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.EnableMoveTracking
member.summary: Enables the Move Tracking response during move commands. The device will return its position periodically when a move command is executed. The Disable Auto-Reply option above takes precedence over this option. The default is off on all devices. Before firmware version 5.14, only Move at Constant Speed commands could generate tracking responses, now all move commands can.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.DisableManualMoveTracking
member.summary: Disables the Manual Move Tracking response during manual moves. The Disable Auto-Reply option above takes precedence over this option.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.EnableMessageIdsMode
member.summary: Enables the Message Ids Mode. In this mode of communication, only bytes 3 thru 5 are used for data. Byte 6 is used as an ID byte that the user can set to any value they wish. It will be returned unchanged in the reply. Logic Channel Mode allows the user application to monitor communication packets individually to implement error detection and recovery.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.HomeStatus
member.summary: This bit is set to 0 automatically on power-up or reset. It is set automatically when the device is homed or when the position is set using command #45. It can be used to detect if a unit has a valid position reference. It can also be set or cleared by the user.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.DisableAutoHome
member.summary: Disables auto-home checking. Checking for trigger of home sensor is only done when home command is issued. This allows rotational devices to move multiple revolutions without retriggering the home sensor.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.EnableCircularPhaseMicrostepping
member.summary: Enables circular phase micro-stepping mode. Square phase micro-stepping is employed by default. See your user manual or the wiki for the differences.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.SetHomeSwitchLogic
member.summary: Some devices have active high home limit switches. A value of 1 must be set for these devices for the device to home properly. On devices with built in motors and home sensors, the factory default settings will be correct. However, some devices, such as the T-CD series can accept a variety of motors and home sensors. On these devices, this bit may need to be changed from the default setting in order for the home sensor to function correctly. See the recommended settings for your particular device. Damage to the home sensor or actuator may result if this bit is set improperly.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.DisablePowerLed
member.summary: Turns off the green power LED. It will still blink briefly, immediately after powerup.

member.name: F:Zaber.DeviceModes.DisableSerialLed
member.summary: Turns off the yellow serial LED.

member.name: T:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade
member.summary: This is the main class that most applications will interact with.
member.remarks:
The standard pattern is:
Call and display them to the user.
When the user picks one, pass it to .
Either call to get a specific device, call to get the all of them, call to get a specific conversation, or call to get all of them.
Either make requests from conversations or send commands to devices and register to receive the response events.
See the ZaberDeviceDemo and ZaberConversationDemo projects for some example code.

member.name: P:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade.AllConversations
member.summary: Gets a list of all conversations for all the devices, their alias numbers, and individual axes.
member.remarks:
This collection includes conversations of all attached devices, their alias conversations (if the alias number is non-zero and does not collide with an existent conversation), their axis conversations, and the "All Device" conversation ( 0).
This collection include individual axes (non-zero ). Also see .

member.name: P:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade.AreDeviceNumbersValidated
member.summary: Get or set a flag that will raise a port error for an invalid packet if a response packet has an unknown device number.

member.name: P:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade.AreMessageIdsEnabled
member.summary: Enables or disables message ids mode on all devices attached to the port.

remarks.para: Message ids mode uses id numbers to match each response to the request that triggered it. Message ids are also known as logical channels.

The Zaber port facade forces you to keep the message ids mode the same on all devices attached to the port, either all on or all off. This avoids major confusion after a renumber request. Setting this property will trigger a "Return Setting" command for the device mode. The Zaber port facade will automatically send "Set Device Mode" commands to switch any devices that don't match the requested setting. It will continue to do this whenever it sees a "Set Device Mode" response with the wrong setting of message ids mode.

member.name: P:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade.BaudRate

member.name: P:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade.Conversations
member.summary: Gets a list of all conversations for all devices and their alias numbers.
member.remarks:
This collection includes conversations of all attached devices, their alias conversations (if the alias number is non-zero and does not collide with an existent conversation), and the "All Device" conversation ( 0).
This collection does not include individual axes (non-zero ). Also see .

member.name: E:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade.Closed
member.summary: Raised when the port facade is closed.

member.name: E:Zaber.ZaberPortFacade.Invalidated
member.summary: Raised when the port facade is invalidated and should be reopened.
member.remarks: The port facade is invalidated when the list of connected devices may have become inaccurate. This happens after a response to the Renumber command, the Convert to ASCII/Binary command, the RestoreSettings command, or the SetAlias command. If client applications want to be sure the device list is accurate, they should call and then to reopen the port and requery the list of connected devices. The event is only raised the first time the facade is invalidated, so if two renumber commands are sent without reopening the port facade in between, only the first one will raise this event.

member.name: E:Zaber.IZaberPort.DataPacketReceived
member.summary: Raised when the port receives data back from the devices. When a complete response has been received, it's converted to a object and sent through this event.

remarks.para: Be careful when handling this event, because it is usually raised from a background thread. The simplest way to deal with that is not to register for this event at all. Use a to coordinate requests and responses instead. It handles all the threading issues and just returns the response as the return value from .

If you do want to handle this event safely in your user interface, read the first two sections of this article: http://weblogs.asp.net/justin_rogers/articles/126345.aspx It shows how to use Control.InvokeRequired and Control.BeginInvoke to move execution back onto the UI thread from a background thread.

member.name: M:Zaber.ZaberDevice.FormatData(System.Int32,Zaber.UnitOfMeasure)
member.summary: Display a data value in another unit of measure. Requires certain commands to be present in the 's list of commands. See remarks for details.
member.param: The data value to display.
The unit of measure to convert to.
member.remarks:
To convert from data to a position, DeviceType.Commands must contain the "Set Current Position" command in either ASCII ("pos") or Binary (command 45). To convert from data to a velocity, it must contain the "Set Target Speed" command, which is called "maxspeed" in ASCII and is command number 42 in Binary. Finally, to convert from data to an acceleration, the commands list must contain the "Set Acceleration" command, which is "accel" in ASCII and command 43 in Binary.
Regardless of which kind of conversion is taking place, the relevant command must have ites "RequestUnit", "RequestUnitScale", and "RequestUnitFunction" properties set in order to provide sufficient information for conversion.
member.exception: The 's "Commands" list did not contain the required command to perform the conversion to the unit of measure specified.
member.returns: A string representation of the data value. Rounded to one decimal place beyond the device's microstep size.

member.name: M:Zaber.ZaberDevice.ApplyScalingFunction(Zaber.ScalingFunction,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Apply a given scaling function to a real-life unit to get the equivalent device unit.
member.param: The scaling function.
A number by which physical units scale to the device's units.
The unit to be scaled.
The microstep resolution of the device. Only requred when scalingFunction is LinearResolution or TangentialResolution.
member.remarks: has no unit associated with it (it is not a Measurement). This function will blindly apply the scale to the unit, assuming they are consistent with one another. It is up to the user of this function to ensure that the physical measurement provided is in the same unit as expected by the scale. For example, if is a scaling factor between microsteps and metres, physicalUnits should be in metres.
member.returns: A number of microsteps which should move the device the proper distance, according to the scale.

member.summary: Calculate a measurement for a given data value.
member.param: The command that the data value is for.

member.returns: A measurement in the appropriate unit of measure, or as raw data if it couldn't be converted.

member.name: M:Zaber.ZaberDevice.ReverseScalingFunction(Zaber.ScalingFunction,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Like ApplyScalingFunction, but in reverse. Takes a number of microsteps and applies a scaling function in reverse to return a physical unit.
member.param: The scaling function to be (un-)applied.
The scaling constant.
A number of microsteps to be converted into a real-life unit.
The microstep resolution. Can be omitted if the scaling function does not use it.
member.remarks: Like ApplyScalingFunction, this function is blind to units. This means that the integer returned will depend entirely on the unit which represents. For example, if scale represents the scale between microsteps and metres, then the return value of this function will be in metres.
member.returns: An integer representing a physical measurement.

member.name: T:Zaber.DataPacket
member.summary: A collection of all the data that gets sent to and received from the T-Series devices.
member.remarks: This class is mostly used inside the Zaber library. It converts the commands to byte streams and back again. The place that client programs will see it is in the event handler.

member.name: M:Zaber.DataPacket.#ctor
member.summary: Initialize the data structure with all values set to zero.

member.name: M:Zaber.DataPacket.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Parse a text message into a data packet.
member.param: parse details from this text
member.remarks: Expected format for reply message is `@dd a [mm ]ff ssss ww xxxx[:CC]` where dd is the device number, a is the axis number, mm is the message ID, ff is a flag (OK or RJ for reject), ssss is the status (IDLE or BUSY), ww is the top warning flag, xxxx is a list of one or more data values, and CC is the checksum.
member.exception: The text could not be parsed and so is malformed.

member.name: M:Zaber.DataPacket.#ctor(Zaber.DataPacket)
member.summary: Copy constructor.
member.param: copy details from this packet

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.Data
member.summary: Data value to go with the command
member.value: Any integer value, positive or negative. Details depend on the different command values. See the user manual.
member.remarks: For ASCII responses with multiple data values, this will hold the first data value. will hold all the data values. If the data value is text, then this will be zero.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.DataValues
member.summary: An array of data values to go with the command
member.value: An array of integer values, positive or negative. Deatils depend on the different commands. See the user manual.
member.remarks: If any of the data values are text, then the corresponding entry will be zero. will hold the text version of each data value.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.Measurement
member.summary: Gets or sets a measurement that represents the data value in another unit of measure.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.Command
member.summary: The specific command to execute. See the user manual for a list of supported commands and the data values they support. Some common commands are listed in the enumeration.
member.value: You can assign any byte value, but you have to cast it to a Command type first.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.DeviceNumber
member.summary: The device number in the chain that this command should be sent to or was received from.
member.remarks: You can send a command directly to a device, or send a command to an alias device number. 0 is always an alias for all devices, and each device can set another alias number. Several devices can use the same alias, and all of them will respond to a command using the alias device number.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.AxisNumber
member.summary: Gets or sets the axis number on the device that this command should be sent to or was received from.
member.remarks: You can send a command directly to an axis, or send a command to all axes on the device. Axis number 0 represents all axes on the device.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.MessageIdType
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of message ID in this message.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.MessageId
member.summary: Gets or sets the message ID corresponding to this message.
member.remarks:
Message Ids allow you to coordinate responses with the requests that triggered them.
In T-series Binary protocol, messages Ids are also known as logical channels.

member.name: M:Zaber.DataPacket.FormatRequest
member.summary: Format the data packet as a string, assuming that it was sent as a request.
member.returns: The message as a string

member.name: M:Zaber.DataPacket.FormatResponse
member.summary: Format the message as a string, assuming that it was sent as a response.
member.returns: The message as a string

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.IsError
member.summary: Gets a flag showing if this packet is an error message.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.IsAgain
member.summary: Gets a flag showing if this packet is an error message with the AGAIN response.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.HasFault
member.summary: Gets a flag showing if this packet has a warning flag that is a fault.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.TextData
member.summary: Gets the data field from a text-mode response, otherwise null.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.FlagText
member.summary: Gets the flag field from a text-mode response, otherwise null.

member.name: P:Zaber.DataPacket.TextDataValues
member.summary: Gets the individual data values from a text-mode response, otherwise null.

member.remarks: This object used to be used to make sure no handler subscribed to this class' events ran too long, as each was executed synchronously. It is now deprecated: All events handlers are now called asynchronously, so it doesn't matter if they run long sometimes. It is the responsibility of the subscribed method to not run long/be "badly behaved", not of the class which raises the event.

member.name: M:Zaber.TSeriesPort.ReportInvalidPacket
member.summary: Report that an invalid packet was received by raising the event.
member.remarks: This can be called by any higher-level code that decides a packet was invalid. An example would be if the device number doesn't match any known devices.

member.name: E:Zaber.TSeriesPort.DataPacketReceived
member.summary: Raised when the port receives data back from the devices. When a complete response has been received, it's converted to a object and sent through this event.

remarks.para: Be careful when handling this event, because it is usually raised from a background thread. The simplest way to deal with that is not to register for this event at all. Use a to coordinate requests and responses instead. It handles all the threading issues and just returns the response as the return value from .

If you do want to handle this event safely in your user interface, read the first two sections of this article: http://weblogs.asp.net/justin_rogers/articles/126345.aspx It shows how to use Control.InvokeRequired and Control.BeginInvoke to move execution back onto the UI thread from a background thread.

member.name: E:Zaber.TSeriesPort.DataPacketSent
member.summary: Raised when the port sends data to the devices.
member.remarks: Be careful when handling this event, because it is occasionally raised from a background thread. See for details. Some scenarios where it can be raised from a background thread are: executing scripts and automatically adjusting message id mode.

member.name: E:Zaber.TSeriesPort.ErrorReceived
